title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0001
text: Which package contains the Queue interface?
explanation: The Queue interface is part of the java.util package.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0002
text: Which of the following interfaces does Queue extend?
explanation: The Queue interface extends the Collection interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0003
text: Which of the following is the primary purpose of a Queue?

options.text: To hold elements prior to processing

explanation: A Queue is used to hold elements prior to processing, typically in FIFO order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0004
text: Which of the following classes implement the Queue interface?
explanation: LinkedList, PriorityQueue, and ArrayDeque are common implementations of the Queue interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0005
text: Which of the following methods inserts an element into a queue?
explanation: The offer() method inserts an element into the queue and returns false if the queue is full.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0006
text: Which of the following methods retrieves and removes the head of the queue?
explanation: The poll() method retrieves and removes the head of the queue, returning null if the queue is empty.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0007
text: Which of the following methods retrieves but does not remove the head of the queue?
explanation: The peek() method retrieves but does not remove the head of the queue, returning null if empty.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0008
text: Which of the following methods throws an exception if the queue is empty when removing an element?
explanation: The remove() method throws NoSuchElementException if the queue is empty.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0009
text: Which of the following methods throws an exception if the queue is full when adding an element?
explanation: The add() method throws an IllegalStateException if the queue is full.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0010
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and ordering?

options.text: Queue typically orders elements in FIFO order
Queue orders elements in LIFO order
Queue orders elements by hash code

explanation: Queue typically follows FIFO (First-In-First-Out) ordering.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0011
text: Which of the following is true about PriorityQueue?

options.text: PriorityQueue orders elements according to their natural ordering

explanation: PriorityQueue orders elements according to their natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0012
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and null elements?

options.text: Most Queue implementations do not allow null elements
All Queue implementations allow null elements

explanation: Most Queue implementations, such as PriorityQueue, do not allow null elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0013
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and duplicates?

options.text: Queue throws an exception for duplicates

explanation: Queue allows duplicate elements unless restricted by a specific implementation.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0014
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and blocking behavior?

options.text: BlockingQueue implementations support waiting for space or elements
Queue blocks all operations by default

explanation: BlockingQueue implementations like ArrayBlockingQueue support waiting for space or elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0015
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and Deque?

options.text: Deque extends Queue and supports insertion/removal at both ends
Deque is a subtype of List

explanation: Deque extends Queue and supports insertion and removal at both ends.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and LinkedList?

options.text: LinkedList implements both List and Queue interfaces

explanation: LinkedList implements both List and Queue interfaces, allowing it to function as a queue.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and ArrayDeque?

options.text: ArrayDeque implements Deque and can be used as a Queue

explanation: ArrayDeque implements Deque and can be used as a Queue or Stack.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and PriorityQueue?

options.text: PriorityQueue orders elements based on priority

explanation: PriorityQueue orders elements based on their natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0019
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and synchronization?

options.text: Queue is not synchronized by default

explanation: The Queue interface is not synchronized by default; synchronization can be achieved using concurrent implementations.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and thread safety?
explanation: ConcurrentLinkedQueue is a thread-safe implementation of the Queue interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0021
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and BlockingQueue?

options.text: BlockingQueue extends Queue and supports blocking operations
BlockingQueue is a subtype of Set

explanation: BlockingQueue extends Queue and supports operations that wait for the queue to become non-empty or non-full.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0022
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and null elements in PriorityQueue?

options.text: PriorityQueue does not allow null elements

explanation: PriorityQueue does not allow null elements because null cannot be compared.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and duplicates?

options.text: Queue throws an exception for duplicates

explanation: Queue allows duplicate elements unless restricted by a specific implementation.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and FIFO order?

options.text: Queue follows FIFO order by default
Queue follows LIFO order by default

explanation: Queue follows FIFO (First-In-First-Out) order by default.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and Deque?

options.text: Deque supports insertion and removal at both ends
Deque supports insertion only at the head
Deque supports removal only at the tail

explanation: Deque extends Queue and supports insertion and removal at both ends.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0026
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and ArrayDeque?

options.text: ArrayDeque does not allow null elements

explanation: ArrayDeque does not allow null elements because null is used as a special return value.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and LinkedList?

options.text: LinkedList implements both Queue and Deque

explanation: LinkedList implements both Queue and Deque interfaces.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and BlockingQueue implementations?
explanation: ArrayBlockingQueue and LinkedBlockingQueue are implementations of the BlockingQueue interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and thread safety?
explanation: ConcurrentLinkedQueue is a thread-safe implementation of the Queue interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and fail-fast behavior?

options.text: Iterators of most Queue implementations are fail-fast

explanation: Iterators of most Queue implementations are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and peek()?

options.text: peek() retrieves but does not remove the head

explanation: The peek() method retrieves but does not remove the head of the queue.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and poll()?

options.text: poll() retrieves and removes the head
poll() retrieves but does not remove the head

explanation: The poll() method retrieves and removes the head of the queue.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and element()?

options.text: element() retrieves but does not remove the head and throws exception if empty

explanation: The element() method retrieves but does not remove the head and throws NoSuchElementException if empty.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and add()?

options.text: add() inserts an element and throws exception if full
add() inserts an element and returns false if full

explanation: The add() method inserts an element and throws IllegalStateException if the queue is full.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and offer()?

options.text: offer() inserts an element and returns false if full

explanation: The offer() method inserts an element and returns false if the queue is full.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and remove()?

options.text: remove() retrieves and removes the head and throws exception if empty
remove() retrieves but does not remove the head

explanation: The remove() method retrieves and removes the head and throws NoSuchElementException if empty.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and BlockingQueue methods?

options.text: put() and take() block until space or elements are available
put() and take() throw exceptions if full or empty
put() and take() remove all elements
put() and take() clear the queue

explanation: The put() and take() methods in BlockingQueue block until space or elements are available.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and PriorityBlockingQueue?

options.text: PriorityBlockingQueue is an unbounded thread-safe queue

explanation: PriorityBlockingQueue is an unbounded thread-safe queue that orders elements according to their priority.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and DelayQueue?

options.text: DelayQueue holds elements until their delay expires

explanation: DelayQueue holds elements until their delay time has expired.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and SynchronousQueue?

options.text: SynchronousQueue has no capacity and each insert must wait for a remove

explanation: SynchronousQueue has no capacity; each insert operation must wait for a corresponding remove operation.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and LinkedBlockingQueue?

options.text: LinkedBlockingQueue is optionally bounded and thread-safe
LinkedBlockingQueue is unbounded and not thread-safe

explanation: LinkedBlockingQueue is optionally bounded and thread-safe.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and ArrayBlockingQueue?

options.text: ArrayBlockingQueue is a bounded blocking queue backed by an array

explanation: ArrayBlockingQueue is a bounded blocking queue backed by an array.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and ConcurrentLinkedQueue?

options.text: ConcurrentLinkedQueue is an unbounded thread-safe queue

explanation: ConcurrentLinkedQueue is an unbounded thread-safe queue based on linked nodes.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and ordering in PriorityQueue?

options.text: PriorityQueue orders elements by natural order or comparator

explanation: PriorityQueue orders elements by their natural order or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and null elements in ArrayDeque?

options.text: ArrayDeque does not allow null elements

explanation: ArrayDeque does not allow null elements because null is used as a special return value.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and Deque methods?

options.text: Deque provides addFirst() and addLast() methods

explanation: Deque provides addFirst() and addLast() methods for insertion at both ends.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and poll() vs remove()?

options.text: poll() returns null if empty, remove() throws exception
poll() throws exception if empty, remove() returns null

explanation: poll() returns null if the queue is empty, while remove() throws NoSuchElementException.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and peek() vs element()?

options.text: peek() returns null if empty, element() throws exception
peek() throws exception if empty, element() returns null

explanation: peek() returns null if the queue is empty, while element() throws NoSuchElementException.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about the Queue interface and capacity?
explanation: Some Queue implementations like ArrayBlockingQueue are bounded, while others like LinkedList are unbounded.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkQueue - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes the Queue interface?

options.text: A collection designed for holding elements prior to processing, typically in FIFO order
A collection that stores unique elements only
A collection that maps keys to values
A collection that maintains sorted order only

explanation: The Queue interface represents a collection designed for holding elements prior to processing, typically in FIFO order.
